title: Swinburne Examples of Digital Literacies in Curriculum  Science

transcript.text: Beta identified uh an online access as
one of her major issues when looking at
equitable assessment during semester 1.
So her cohort um she had quite a large
cohort um and they all had varying
access to the internet so the scheduled
synchronous oral presentations weren't
an option. Um and I think that was the
case for quite a lot of us. As a
solution, she chose a new delivery
format for oral presentations to allow
for equitable access during co. What she
decided to do was to create um uh and
reimagine this assessment item to
support students to layer their work
digitally using text, images, and a
scrolling interface.
Students were then also asked to embed
uh video which was made with the same
Adobe program. And then so that captured
part of their oral presentation and then
they delivered the rest of their oral
presentation in different communication
forms. So in text uh or images. So I'd
like to just show you some examples um
of the student work. Uh you can see here
they're putting in a graph which is
fantastic and this interface supports
that. Um and really the the work that we
were talking about too is the
relationship that happens between text
and images and video. So this is a video
here and then there's actually uh
speaking to camera that happened as
well. Um
so beta gave the stools the the uh the
tools to the students to create a
layered artifact that could be used um
also in a live context postco. So that's
what's lovely about this as well. So
this work was a standalone work but
postco they can also use it as a
presentation um tool to replace
PowerPoint slides. In this case the
rubrics were altered to take into
account the live elements of the oral
presentation that couldn't be captured
in this moment but those elements were
replaced with new literacies that
encompassed other communication formats.
Um, so that's an example from science.
